conclusion: Four stationary blocks labeled A, B, C, and D are on a round table.
Two moving objects labeled A and B are flying through the air and will be released directly above the respective stationary spots shown in the image.
Gravity will cause each flying object to fall straight down onto the block or location with the same letter designation.
The primary interaction between the falling objects and stationary blocks is a collision.
The outcome of a collision depends on mass, shape, relative speed, surface friction, and rigidity of the materials.

In an idealized description with rigid objects, no sticking, and moderate speeds, the incoming object will either bounce slightly if the impact is elastic or come to rest on top of the stationary block if the collision is sufficiently inelastic.
Ordinary tabletop objects like plastic or wooden blocks at moderate drop heights generally undergo mostly inelastic collisions.
Dropped objects lose most of their translational kinetic energy to sound, heat, and minor deformation, then settle.
Unless the dropped object’s center of mass overhangs the block’s edges or is spinning wildly, it will land and remain balanced.
Each falling object A and B will land on the corresponding stationary block A and B.
The falling objects will momentarily impact, lose speed, and then rest on the top surfaces of the blocks.
The neighboring stationary blocks C and D are unaffected except for a small transmitted vibration through the tabletop.
Final answer: The airborne objects A and B fall under gravity, collide inelastically with the blocks at positions A and B, and come to rest on top of them; blocks C and D remain unchanged.
